message.content:
We need to look only for transactions of type “Depreciation” – since these adjust the accumulated depreciation balance.

Step 1. Review the data and find depreciation entries:

• The first depreciation is on 2024‑01‑01 (id “Depreciation20240101001”) with an amount of 45748.2.

• The second depreciation is on 2024‑02‑01 (id “Depreciation20240201002”) with an amount of 54491.69 (numerically it is “54491.689999999995”, which rounds to 54491.69).

Step 2. The beginning balance of accumulated depreciation is assumed to be 0.00 (since no prior depreciation is recorded during the period).

Step 3. The ending accumulated depreciation is the sum of these two values:
  45748.2 + 54491.69 = 100239.89

Thus the accumulated depreciation at the start is 0.00 and at the end is 100239.89.

Below is the JSON solution answer.

  
```json
{"solution": {"Accumulated Depreciation Initial Value": "0.00", "Accumulated Depreciation End Value": "100239.89"} }
```
